semantic_title: Coding Guidelines for Sequelae of Cerebrovascular Disease Including Dominant Side Rules
section_path: Section I > C. Chapter-Specific Coding Guidelines > 9. Diseases of the Circulatory System > d. Sequelae of Cerebrovascular Disease > 1) Category I69, Sequelae of Cerebrovascular disease

content.full_text: Category I69 is used to indicate conditions classifiable to categories I60-I67 as the causes of sequela (neurologic deficits), themselves classified elsewhere. These "late effects" include neurologic deficits that persist after initial onset of conditions classifiable to categories I60-I67. The neurologic deficits caused by cerebrovascular disease may be present from the onset or may arise at any time after the onset of the condition classifiable to categories I60-I67. Codes from category I69, Sequelae of cerebrovascular disease, that specify hemiplegia, hemiparesis and monoplegia identify whether the dominant or nondominant side is affected. Should the affected side be documented, but not specified as dominant or nondominant, and the classification system does not indicate a default, code selection is as follows: • For ambidextrous patients, the default should be dominant. • If the left side is affected, the default is non-dominant. • If the right side is affected, the default is dominant. (Evidence: pg no: 53, L65-L73)
content.summary: Guidelines for coding sequelae of cerebrovascular disease with specific rules for determining dominant vs non-dominant side (Evidence: pg no: 53, L65-L73)
key_concepts: Category I69 for sequelae (Evidence: pg no: 53, L65-L66)
Late effects of I60-I67 conditions (Evidence: pg no: 53, L66-L69)
Neurologic deficits timing (Evidence: pg no: 53, L68-L69)
Dominant vs non-dominant side coding (Evidence: pg no: 53, L69-L70)
Default side assignment rules (Evidence: pg no: 53, L70-L73)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Use category I69 for sequelae of cerebrovascular disease (Evidence: pg no: 53, L65-L66)
detailed_rules.explanation: Category I69 indicates conditions classifiable to categories I60-I67 as causes of neurologic sequelae that are classified elsewhere (Evidence: pg no: 53, L65-L67)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Neurologic deficits may be present from onset or arise later (Evidence: pg no: 53, L68-L69)
detailed_rules.explanation: The neurologic deficits caused by cerebrovascular disease may be present from the onset or may arise at any time after the onset of the I60-I67 condition (Evidence: pg no: 53, L68-L69)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Apply default rules for dominant/non-dominant side when not specified (Evidence: pg no: 53, L70-L73)
detailed_rules.explanation: When affected side is documented but dominance not specified, use defaults: ambidextrous = dominant, left side = non-dominant, right side = dominant (Evidence: pg no: 53, L70-L73)
detailed_rules.applies_to: I69 codes with hemiplegia, hemiparesis, monoplegia

workflow_steps: Step 2: Determine if neurologic deficits present
Step 3: Check for hemiplegia, hemiparesis, or monoplegia
Step 5: Apply dominant/non-dominant defaults if needed

code_ranges.description: Sequelae of cerebrovascular disease (Evidence: pg no: 53, L65-L66)
code_ranges.requirement: Use for neurologic sequelae of I60-I67 conditions
usage_rules: Apply dominant/non-dominant defaults when needed (Evidence: pg no: 53, L70-L73)

code_ranges.description: Cerebrovascular diseases that can cause sequelae (Evidence: pg no: 53, L66-L67)
code_ranges.requirement: Original conditions that lead to sequelae
usage_rules: May be coded with I69 if current disease present (Evidence: pg no: 53, L66-L67)

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient with right-sided weakness following stroke
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Right hemiparesis following cerebral infarction, dominance not specified
step_by_step: Step 3: Apply default rule: right side = dominant
Step 4: Assign I69 code for dominant side hemiparesis

correct_coding.rationale: Right-sided hemiparesis defaults to dominant side when dominance not specified (Evidence: pg no: 53, L70-L73)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Would be incorrect non-dominant coding for right side

warnings: Must apply default dominance rules when not documented (Evidence: pg no: 53, L70-L73)
best_practices: Check for neurologic deficit documentation (Evidence: pg no: 53, L68-L69)
Apply side dominance defaults consistently (Evidence: pg no: 53, L70-L73)
common_mistakes: Not using I69 codes for stroke sequelae
tips: Remember deficits can arise at any time after stroke (Evidence: pg no: 53, L68-L69)
